title: Sorted ValueSet - a Data Oriented Set
narrative:
A sorted `ValueSet` is a fundamental building block in sprouts' data-oriented programming model.
    It represents an immutable collection of unique and sorted elements, providing an API focused on
    deriving new sets from existing ones rather than mutating state. Unlike traditional
    Java sets, all operations return new `ValueSet` instances, making it ideal for
    functional-style programming and safe concurrent usage.

    This specification tests the behavior of the `ValueSet` when created using the
    "sorted" factory methods, which produce sets that maintain their elements in a sorted order.
    This is similar to the JDK's `TreeSet`, but with the added benefits of immutability,
    structural sharing and enabling of functional programming designs.

features.id: An empty sorted `ValueSet` can be created by specifying the element type

extraInfo:
A `ValueSet` needs to be created with a type to allow for better
            type safety during runtime as well as improved performance
            due to primitive specialization.
            A `ValueSet` based on the `Integer` class for example, will
            internally use a primitive `int[]` array to store the values.

features.id: The sorted `ValueSet` maintains invariance with a Java Set across operations [0]

code: "The size of the set and the value set are not equal after element '$element' was introduced "+
"with operation '$operation'. Set size: ${referenceSet.size()}, Value set size: ${currentSet.size()}"

blocks.text: Apply operations first time
Immediate invariance
Apply operations multiple times
Consistent state
Their entry sets converted to lists are equal.
We use the stream API to map both the value set and the JDK based reference set.
The mapped value set and mapped set are equal.
We use the parallel stream API to map both the value set and the reference set.
The mapped value set and JDK set are equal in terms of their contents.

operations:
new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, "apple"),
                new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, "banana"),
                new Tuple2(Operation.REMOVE, "apple")
        ]

blocks.text: Elements are removed regardless of input collection type

features.id: You can remove items from a sorted value set selectively, using `removeIf(Predicate)`. [0]

extraInfo:
You can remove elements from a value set which satisfy
            a given `Predicate`. Or in other words,
            if the `Predicate.test(Object)` method yields `true` for a particular
            element, then it will be removed, otherwise, it will remain in the
            returned set.

blocks.text: We create a sorted value set and a regular JDK set containing some test elements.
We apply a predicate to both types of sets...
They contain the same elements!

elements: ['a' as char, 'x' as char, '4' as char, '#' as char]

features.id: You can keep items in a sorted value set selectively, using `retainIf(Predicate)`. [0]

extraInfo:
You can keep elements in a value set which satisfy
            a given `Predicate` and have them removed otherwise. Or in other words,
            if the `Predicate.test(Object)` method yields `false` for a particular
            element, then it will be removed, otherwise, it will remain in the
            returned set.

blocks.text: We create a sorted value set and a regular JDK set containing some test elements.

We apply a predicate to both types of sets...
            In case of the JDK set we use the negation of `removeIf`,
            which does the same thing effectively.
They contain the same elements!

elements: ['a' as char, 'x' as char, '4' as char, '#' as char]

features.id: retainAll works with diverse collection sources

blocks.text: Only elements present in both collections are retained

features.id: The various `containsAll(..)` methods accurately check membership across collection types.

blocks.text: Membership checks work with all compatible collection types
code: valueSet.containsAll([] as Set) // Empty collection always returns true

features.id: operations with empty collections have no effect or clear as expected

blocks.text: Empty inputs leave set unchanged or clear appropriately
Retaining nothing clears the set

features.id: Bulk operations ignore duplicate elements in input

blocks.text: Duplicates in input collections have no effect

features.id: A sorted value set interoperates with a `Tuple`

blocks.text: Full interoperability with Tuple collections

features.id: A sorted `ValueSet` collector works with different stream sources.

blocks.text: Collecting from various stream sources
All collected sets match source contents

features.id: A no-op operations returns the same instance!

blocks.text: The identity is preserved when operations don't modify a set.
Adding existing elements does not change the set.

features.id: Use `ValueSet.classTyped(Class)` to created a typed class pointer to `ValueSet`.
A sorted set of strings can have a custom comparator.
A sorted set of integers can have a custom comparator.
A sorted set can directly be created from tuples.
Use the `toSet()` method to convert a sorted `ValueSet` to an unmodifiable JDK `Set`.

code: var sortedSet = ValueSet.ofSorted("oat milk", "almond milk", "soy milk")
jdkSet.add("coconut milk") // This should throw an exception since the set is unmodifiable.

features.id: The `equals` and `hashCode` implementations of a sorted ValueSet works reliably after removing a large part of elements. [0]

extraInfo:
Here we test the implementation of the `equals` and `hashCode` methods exhaustively.
            This may look like an exaggerated amount of test data and equality checks, but you
            have to know that under the hood specifically the `equals` implementations are
            highly optimized to specific cases which need to be covered.

            More specifically, if there are only small differences between sorted value set,
            we can avoid a lot of work due to two set sharing most of their branches.

blocks.text: We create randomly sorted variants of the test data:
code: var keyHasher1 = { (64 * it.hashCode() * (1997 * it.hashCode() ** 2)%1024) as int }
var keyHasher2 = { (31 * it.hashCode() * (1997 * it.hashCode() ** 2)%256) as int }

blocks.text: We create two different sorted `ValueSet` instances from the two scrambled list...
The two sets are equal!
They also have the same hash codes:
We create versions of the sets where parts are removed...
They are equal...
We make them different by adding to them...
code: var toAdd2 = subList.subList((subList.size() * 0.5) as int, subList.size()).toSet()

blocks.text: We use the following entry data source:

blocks.text: We use the following entry data source:

features.id: The `removeIf(Class)` method filters out items of the specified type while preserving the sorted value set characteristics.

extraInfo:
The `removeIf(Class)` method creates a new sorted value set containing only items that are NOT 
            instances of the specified type. This is useful for filtering out specific types from 
            a heterogeneous value set.

            Important behavior for sorted variant:
            - The returned value set maintains the sorted ordering characteristics
            - Items that are instances of the specified type (including subclasses) are removed
            - The element type of the returned value set remains the same as the original
            - The remaining elements maintain their sorted order

blocks.text: A sorted value set with mixed types
code: var mixed = ValueSet.ofSorted(Number, Comparator.comparingDouble {it as double}).addAll(1 as byte, 42, 2 as byte, 3.14d, 3 as byte, 100, 4 as byte)

blocks.text: We remove all Byte instances
Only non-String items remain in sorted order
We remove all Integer instances
Only non-Integer items remain in sorted order
code: withoutIntegers.toList() == [1 as byte, 2 as byte, 3 as byte, 3.14d, 4 as byte]

blocks.text: We remove all Double and Integer instances:
Only non-Number items remain in sorted order
code: withoutNumbers.toList() == [1 as byte, 2 as byte, 3 as byte, 4 as byte]

features.id: The `retainIf(Class)` method keeps only items of the specified type and returns a properly typed sorted value set.

extraInfo:
The `retainIf(Class)` method creates a new sorted value set containing only items that ARE 
            instances of the specified type. This is useful for extracting specific types from 
            a heterogeneous value set.

            Important behavior for sorted variant:
            - Only items that are instances of the specified type (including subclasses) are retained
            - The returned value set is properly typed as ValueSet<V> where V is the specified type
            - The sorted ordering characteristics are preserved in the result
            - The retained elements are sorted according to the original comparator

blocks.text: A sorted value set with mixed types
code: var mixed = ValueSet.ofSorted(Number, Comparator.comparingDouble {it as double}).addAll(1 as byte, 42, 2 as byte, 3.14d, 3 as byte, 100, 4 as byte)

blocks.text: We retain only Byte instances
Only Byte items remain in sorted order and result is properly typed
code: onlyByte.toList() == [1 as byte, 2 as byte, 3 as byte, 4 as byte]

blocks.text: We retain only Integer instances
Only Integer items remain in sorted order and result is properly typed
We retain only Double instances...
All doubles remain in sorted order and result is properly typed

features.id: The `removeIf(Class)` method efficiently filters large heterogeneous collections while preserving sorted set characteristics.

extraInfo:
The `removeIf(Class)` method should efficiently handle large collections while 
            maintaining the original sorted value set's characteristics. This test verifies that:

            - Large datasets are processed correctly
            - The operation maintains performance characteristics
            - The result preserves the sorted ordering of the original set
            - Elements are maintained in their proper sorted order

            This is particularly important for data processing pipelines where sorted value sets 
            might contain thousands of heterogeneous elements and sorted order matters.

blocks.text: A sorted value set with a large collection of mixed-type items
We remove all instances of the specified type
The result contains only non-matching items with preserved sorted characteristics

features.id: The `retainIf(Class)` method efficiently extracts typed subsets from large heterogeneous collections while preserving sorted order.

extraInfo:
The `retainIf(Class)` method should efficiently extract homogeneous subsets 
            from large heterogeneous collections while preserving the sorted ordering.
            This test verifies that:

            - Large datasets are processed correctly with proper type filtering
            - The returned value set is properly typed
            - Type safety is maintained throughout the operation
            - Sorted ordering characteristics are preserved
            - Retained elements maintain their proper sorted order

            This is crucial for type-safe data extraction in scenarios where you need to 
            work with specific subtypes from mixed collections and sorted order matters.

blocks.text: A sorted value set with a collection of mixed-type items
We retain only instances of the specified type
The result contains only matching items in sorted order and is properly typed

features.id: Edge cases for `removeIf(Class)` and `retainIf(Class)` methods are handled correctly in sorted value sets.

blocks.text: An empty sorted value set
We try to remove items from an empty set
The empty set is returned unchanged
We try to retain items in an empty set
The empty set is returned unchanged
A sorted value set where no items match the filter criteria for removal
We try to remove String instances from an Integer set
The set is returned unchanged
We try to retain String instances from an Integer set
An empty String sorted set is returned
A sorted value set where all items match the filter criteria for retention
We retain String instances from a String set
The set is returned unchanged (but may be a new instance)
We remove Object instances from a String set (all items are instances)
An empty sorted set is returned

features.id: Sorted value set type filtering preserves sort order across complex operations

extraInfo:
This test verifies that the sorted value set maintains proper sort order
            across multiple type filtering operations, ensuring that the sorting semantics
            are preserved even when performing complex filtering sequences.

blocks.text: A sorted value set with carefully ordered mixed types using custom comparator
We perform sequential type filtering operations
code: var step1 = orderedSet.retainIf(String)  // Keep only strings
var step2 = orderedSet.removeIf(Number)  // Remove all numbers from original
var step3 = step2.retainIf(String)       // Should be same as step1

blocks.text: All operations preserve the sorted ordering

features.id: Custom comparator is preserved when using type filtering methods on sorted value sets

extraInfo:
This test verifies that when using `removeIf(Class)` and `retainIf(Class)` on
            sorted value sets with custom comparators, the resulting value sets maintain
            the same comparator and sorting behavior.

blocks.text: A sorted value set with a custom reverse order comparator
We remove specific types (though all are same type in this case)
code: var result = sortedSet.removeIf(String) // Should remove all since all are Strings

blocks.text: The result maintains the same comparator characteristics
We create a mixed-type set with custom comparator and filter
The filtered set maintains the custom comparator sorting
